questions.questionStr: A relation, R, between two sets A and B (i.e. from A to B) is a --1-- of the --2-- product of A and B.
answers: subset, Cartesian
subset, dot
element, Cartesian
element, dot

questions.questionStr: What notation do we use to say that a is related to b in a given relation R?
answers: 'aRb' or '\(\langle a, b\rangle \in R \)'
'aRb' only
'\(\langle a, b\rangle \in R\)'
Neither - we should write it in words

questions.questionStr: If |A| = n, then how many different binary relations can be created on A?
What relation does the following diagram describe?
answers: \(\{ \langle a_1, b_1 \rangle, \langle a_2, b_1 \rangle, \langle a_2, b_2 \rangle \}\)
\(\{ \langle b_1, a_1 \rangle, \langle b_1, a_2 \rangle, \langle b_2, a_2 \rangle \}\)
\(\{ \langle a_1, b_1 \rangle, \langle a a_2, b_1 \rangle, \langle a_2, b_3 \rangle \}\)

questions.questionStr: What relation does the following diagram describe and what is its type?
answers: The type is \(A^2\), the relation is \(\{ \langle a_1, a_2 \rangle, \langle a_2, a_1 \rangle, \langle a_3, a_2 \rangle, \langle a_3, a_3 \rangle \}\)
The type is \(A\), the relation is \(\{ \langle a_1, a_2 \rangle, \langle a_2, a_1 \rangle, \langle a_3, a_2 \rangle, \langle a_3, a_3 \rangle \}\)
The type is \(A^2\), the relation is \(\{ \langle a_1, a_2 \rangle, \langle a_2, a_1 \rangle, \langle a_3, a_2 \rangle, \langle a_3, a_3 \rangle, \langle a_4, a_4 \rangle \}\)
The type is \(A\), the relation is \({ \langle a_1, a_2 \rangle, \langle a_2, a_1 \rangle, \langle a_3, a_2 \rangle, \langle a_3, a_3 \rangle, \langle a_4, a_4 \rangle}\)

questions.questionStr: What relation does the following matrix represet, given that it is on the sets \(A\) and \(B\), where \(A = {a_1, a_2}\) and \(B = {b_1, b_2, b_3}\)
answers: \(\{ \langle a_1, b_1 \rangle, \langle a_2, b_1 \rangle, \langle a_2, b_2\}\)
\(\langle a_1, b_1 \rangle\, \langle a_1, b_2 \rangle, \langle a_2, b_2 \rangle \)
\(\{ \langle a_1, b_2 \rangle, \langle a_2, b_1 \rangle, \langle a_2, b_2 \}\)
\(\{ \langle a_0, b_0 \rangle, \langle a_1, b_0 \rangle, \langle a_1, b_1\}\)

questions.questionStr: What is an n-ary relation?
answers: An n-ary relation is a relation between n set - i.e. it is a subset of the Cartesian product of n sets. Each element of an n-ary relation is a n-tuple.
An n-ary relation is a relation between n sets - i.e. it is a subset of the Cartesian product of n sets. Each subset of an n-ary relation is a n-tuple.
An n-ary relation is a relation between n set - i.e. it is an element of the Cartesian product of n sets. Each element of an n-ary relation is a n-tuple.
An n-ary relation is a relation between n set - i.e. it is a subset of the Cartesian product of n sets. Each element of an n-ary relation is a set of n values.

questions.questionStr: What are the basic delation operators?
answers: Relation union, relation interesection, relation complement, inverse relation
Relation union, relation intersection, inverse relation
Relation union, relation intersection
Relation union, relation intersection, relation complement, inverse relation, relation projection

questions.questionStr: What is the definition of the relation union operation, between two relations \(R, S \subseteq A \times B\)?
answers: \(R \cup S = \{\langle a, b\rangle \in A 	imes B | \langle a, b \rangle \in S  \text{ or } \langle a, b \rangle \in S \}\)
\(R \cup S = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle \in R \text{ and } \langle a, b \rangle \in S\])

\(R \cup S = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle 
otin R\}\)
\(R \cup S = \{\langle b, a \rangle \in B \times A | \langle a, b \rangle \in R\}\)

questions.questionStr: What is the definition of the relation intersection operation, between two relations \(R, S \subseteq A \times B\)?
answers: \(R \cap S = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle \in R \text{ and } \langle a, b \rangle \in S\])
\(R \cap S = \{\langle a, b\rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle \in S  \text{ or } \langle a, b \rangle \in S \}\)

\(R \cap S = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle 
otin R\}\)
\(R \cap S = \{\langle b, a \rangle \in B \times A | \langle a, b \rangle \in R\}\)

questions.questionStr: What is the definition of the relation complement operation, on a relation \(R \subseteq A \times B\)?
answers:
\(\bar{R} = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle 
otin R\}\)
\(\bar{R} = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle \in R \text{ and } \langle a, b \rangle \in S\])
\(\bar{R} = \{\langle a, b\rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle \in S  \text{ or } \langle a, b \rangle \in S \}\)
\(\bar{R} = \{\langle b, a \rangle \in B \times A | \langle a, b \rangle \in R\}\)

questions.questionStr: What is the definition of the relation inverse operation, on a relation \(R \subseteq A \times B\)?
answers: \(R^{-1} = \{\langle b, a \rangle \in B \times A | \langle a, b \rangle \in R\}\)

\(\bar{R} = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle 
otin R\}\)
\(\bar{R} = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle \in R \text{ and } \langle a, b \rangle \in S\])
\(\bar{R} = \{\langle a, b\rangle \in A \times B | \langle a, b \rangle \in S  \text{ or } \langle a, b \rangle \in S \}\)

questions.questionStr: What is the definition of the identity relation?
answers: \(Id_A = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A^2 | a =_A b\}\)
\(Id_A = \{\langle a, c \rangle \in A \times C | \exists b \in B (\langle a, b \rangle \in R \text{ and } \langle b, c \rangle \in S) \}\)
\(Id_A = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A^2 | a \neq_A b\}\)
\(Id_A = \{\langle a, c \rangle \in A \times B | \exists b \in B (\langle a, b \rangle \in R \text{ or } \langle b, c \rangle \in S) \}\)

questions.questionStr: What is the definition of the composition of some relation R with another relation S, such that \(R \subseteq A \times B\) and \(S \subseteq B \times C\)?
answers: \(R \circ S = \{\langle a, c \rangle \in A \times C | \exists b \in B (\langle a, b \rangle \in R \text{ and } \langle b, c \rangle \in S) \}\)
\(R \circ S = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A^2 | a =_A b\}\)
\(R \circ S = \{\langle a, b \rangle \in A^2 | a \neq_A b\}\)
\(R \circ S = \{\langle a, c \rangle \in A \times B | \exists b \in B (\langle a, b \rangle \in R \text{ or } \langle b, c \rangle \in S) \}\)

questions.questionStr: An --1-- --2-- is a relation that joins terms that are in some sense indistinguishable but not necessarily --3-- as expressions, for example 5 and 3 + 2
answers: equivalence, relation, identical
equivalence, set, identical
equality, relation, equivelant
equality, set, equivelant

questions.questionStr: State the definition of a reflexive relation, R, on the set A
answers: R is reflexive if \(\forall x, y \in A (xRy \implies yRx)\)
R is reflexive if \(\forall x \in A (x R x)\)
R is reflexive if \(\forall x, z \in A (\exists y \in A (xRy \text{ and } yRz) \implies xRz)\)
R is reflexive if \(\forall x, y \in A (x R y)\)

questions.questionStr: State the definition of a symmetric relation, R, on the set A
answers: R is symmetric if \(\forall x \in A (x R x)\)
R is symmetric if \(\forall x, y \in A (xRy \implies yRx)\)
R is symmetric if \(\forall x, z \in A (\exists y \in A (xRy \text{ and } yRz) \implies xRz)\)
R is symmetric if \(\forall x, y \in A (x R y)\)

questions.questionStr: State the definition of a transitive relation, R, on the set A
answers: R is transitive if \(\forall x, z \in A (\exists y \in A (xRy \text{ and } yRz) \implies xRz)\)
R is transitive if \(\forall x, y \in A (xRy \implies yRx)\)
R is transitive if \(\forall x \in A (x R x)\)
R is transitive if \(\forall x, y \in A (x R y)\)

questions.questionStr: Which of the below properties does the relation \(\leq\) on the real numbers satisfy?
answers: Reflexive and transitive but not symmetric
Reflexive, symmetric and transitive
Reflexive and transitive but not symmetric
Symmetric and transitive but not reflexive

questions.questionStr: Which of these defines the reflexivity property of a binary relation in terms of operations on relations?
answers: R is reflexive if and only if \(Id_A \subseteq R\)
R is reflexive if and only if \(R = R^{-1}\)
R is reflexive if and only if \(R \circ R \subseteq R\)
R is reflexive if and only if \(R \subseteq \bar{R}\)

questions.questionStr: Which of these defines the symmetric property of a binary relation in terms of operations on relations?
answers: R is symmetric if and only if \(R = R^{-1}\)
R is symmetric if and only if \(Id_A \subseteq R\)
R is symmetric if and only if \(R \circ R \subseteq R\)
R is symmetric if and only if \(R \subseteq \bar{R}\)

questions.questionStr: Which of these defines the transitive property of a binary relation in terms of operations on relations?
answers: R is transitive if and only if \(R \circ R \subseteq R\)
R is transitive if and only if \(Id_A \subseteq R\)
R is transitive if and only if \(R = R^{-1}\)
R is transitive if and only if \(R \subseteq \bar{R}\)

questions.questionStr: What is the formal definition of an equivelance relation?
answers: A relation is an equivelance relation if it is reflexive, symmetric and transitive
A relation is an equivelance relation if it is reflexive but not symmetric or transitive
A relation is an equivelance relation if it is reflexive and symmetric but not transitive
A relation is an exquivelance relation if it is reflexive and transitive but not symmetric
